questions.text: Most developed paranasal sinus at birth is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ethmoid sinus 1. Embryology of ethmoid sinus: 3-4 cells at birth (most developed paranasal sinus at birth. 2. Formed from 5 ethmoid turbinals (1. agar nasi, 2. uncinate, 3. ethmoid bulla, 4. ground lamella, 5. posterior wall of the most posterior ethmoid cell) 3. Volume at Adult: 10-15 aerated cells ,total volume of 2-3 ml (adult size at 12-15 years old).

Correct Answer (B) Embryology: first to develop in utero, biphasic growth at 3 and 7–18 years old Volume at Adult: typically 15 ml (largest paranasal sinus) Drainage: ethmoid infundibulum (middle meatus, 10–30% have accessory ostium) Maxillary sinus is aka Antrum of Highmore

choices.text: Second bicuspid and first and second molars
Second bicuspid and second and third molars
First bicuspid and first and second molars
First bicuspid and second and third molars

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) second bicuspids (premolar)and first and second molars . -Alveolar process of maxilla contains second bicuspid (Premolar) and first and second molars. -Posterior maxillary wall contains pterygopalatine fossa housing the maxillary artery, pterygopalatine ganglion, and branches of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Most anterior cell of anterior ethmoid group is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Agger Nasi Cells: most anterior of anterior ethmoid cells Ethmoid sinus contains anterior and posterior group of cells . Ground (Basal) Lamella which is the posterior bony insertion of the middle turbinate ,separates the ethmoid into anterior and posterior ethmoid cells . Some of the ethmoidal air cells have been given specific names, because of their importance in surgical procedures or involvement in head and neck pathologies. Onodi Cells: ethmoid cells that pneumatize lateral or posterior to anterior wall of the sphenoid, commonly mistaken as a sphenoid cell, optic nerve may indent into its lateral wall and there are chances of damage to it during surgery . Haller Cells: ethmoid cells that extend into maxillary sinus above the ostium, pneumatize the medial and inferior orbital walls Bulla ethmoidalis - largest ethmoidal group of cells , lie in medial wall of orbit. Note- Lamina Papyracea: lateral thin bony wall of the ethmoid sinus, separates orbit from ethmoid cells as a part of the medial orbital wall. fovea ethmoidalis - roof of ethmoid sinus .

choices.text: Only neurons in adult human that replace themselves
Axones of olfactory nerves are unmyelinated C fibres
Smallest and slowest fibres in nervous system
Mitral cells are tertiary order neurons

questions.text: Pick the false statement regarding olfactory pathway :-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mitral cells are tertiary order neurons The olfactory pathway can be summarized as follows: olfactory receptor cells olfactory nerves olfactory bulb olfactory tract olfactory striae olfactory cortex output targets of the olfactory cortex Olfactory receptors-Basal cells of olfactory epithelium are undifferentiated stem cells, that continuously turn over and replace the olfactory receptors, these are the only neurons in adult human which replace themselves. Olfactory nerve-Axons of olfactory receptor cells (cranial nerve 1 ) . These Carries information from olfactory receptor cells to olfactory bulb. Its axons are unmyelinated C fibres ,These are smallest and slowest fibres in nervous system. Olfactory bulb : Each olfactory bulb (right and left) lies lateral to the crista galli . Within the olfactory bulb are bundles of nerve fibers known as glomeruli; where incoming receptor cell axons make connections with the dendrites of mitral relay neurons. Olfactory tract - This bundle of nerve fibers is made up of the axons of mitral relay neurons bound for the regions of the brain associated with the olfactory cortex.( prepiriform cortex) . Note- CN V (Trigeminal) Carries noxious, painful stimuli E.g. Ammonia. In a fracture of cribriform plate there could be hyposmia or anosmia, however response to ammonia will be intact because this response will be carried by trigemimal nerve .

choices.text: Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1 to 8
Anterior and posterior ethmoid air cells are separated by basal lamella
Bulla ethmoidalis is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell
Haller cells are anterior ethmoidal air cell lying close to orbital floor

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ethmoid air cells
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bulla ethmoidalis is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell. It is also called fourth turbinate. Note Supreme turbinate is a variation. It is another small turbinate sometimes present above superior turbinate. Concha bullosa means pneumatised middle turbinate. Anterior ethmoid air cells are from 2-8. Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1-8 . Haller cell are anterior ethmoid air cells lying in floor of orbit. Ground (Basal) Lamella:posterior bony insertion of the middle turbinate which separates anterior and posterior ethmoid cells.

questions.text: The radiological presence of which paranasal sinus appears last in human life
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Frontal sinus Maxillary sinus :Present at birth and radiologically visualized by 4-5 months of age. Frontal sinus develops in the fourth year of life. It is radiographically visible in children more than 6 year of age. Ethmoid sinus is present at birth. Radiologically appreciable by 1 year of age. Sphenoid sinus develops at second year of life , it is last sinus to finish development .

questions.text: 1st radiological evidence of sphenoid sinus is by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sphenoid sinus becomes radiologically visible at around 4 years of age . Embryology of sphenoid sinus - it develops by evagination of nasal mucosa into sphenoid bone. Volume at Adult: 0.5-8 ml (adult size at 12-18 years old) Drainage: sphenoethmoid recess in the superior meatus Vasculature: sphenopalatine artery (from maxillary artery), maxillary vein (pterygoid plexus) Innervation: sphenopalatine nerve (parasympathetic fibers and V2) Adjacent Structures: pons, pituitary (sella turcica), carotid artery (lateral wall), optic nerve (lateral wall), cavernous sinus (laterally),maxillary and abducens nerves, clivus.

questions.text: Type of sphenoid sinus in adult population is usually:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sellar Hamburger classification :-The types of the sphenoid sinus can be classified in three groups: conchal, presellar, sellar type. Depending on the extent to which the sphenoid bone is pneumatized. In the conchal type, the area below the sella is a solid block of bone without an air cavity. In the presellar type, the sphenoid sinus has moderate air cavity with no sellar indentation. In the sellar type, which is the most common in adult , the corpus of the sphenoid is well pneumatized with full indentation of the sella into the sinus and extends posteriorly until the clivus. Note - The conchal type is most common in children and infrequent in the adult.

questions.text: Uppermost extent of the nose as determined by direct visual inspection :
The internal nasal valve (limen nasi) is bordered by of the following structures except the :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Reference – Otolaryngology by R.Pasha --9 Sol: Nasal Valves Internal Nasal Valve (Limen Nasi): • Bordered by septum, anterior edge of the inferior turbinate, and caudal edge of upper lateral cartilage • Narrowest segment (50% of total nasal resistance) • Potential site of obstruction secondary to bernoulli’s principle • (Narrowed segment accelerates nasal airflow resulting in a decrease in intraluminal pressure)
Correct Answer (B) IMPORTANT POINTS: 1. Humidification ----- 1000 ml of water evaporated/24 hrs from nasal mucosa 2. Ph of nasal secretion --- 7

Correct Answer (D) Each sphenoidal sinus opens into the roof of the nasal cavity via apertures on the posterior wall of the sphenoethmoidal recess directly above the choana. The apertures are located high on the anterior walls of the sinuses themselves. Because only thin shelves of bone separate the sphenoidal sinuses from the nasal cavities below and hypophyseal fossa above, the pituitary gland can be surgically approached through the roof of the nasal cavities by first passing through the anterioinferior aspect of the sphenoid bone and into the sinuses, followed by entry through the top of the sphenoid bone into the hypophyseal fossa. If a fast-growing tumor erodes the floor of the sinus, the vidian nerve could be in danger. If the tumor spreads laterally, the cavernous sinus and all its constituent nerves could be in danger.

Correct Answer (C) The nasolacrimal duct (sometimes called tear duct) carries tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. Excess tears flow through nasolacrimal duct which drains into the inferior nasal meatus. This is the reason the nose starts to run when a person is crying or has watery eyes from an allergy, and why one can sometimes taste eye drops. Like the lacrimal sac, the duct is lined by stratified columnar epithelium containing mucus-secreting goblet cells, and is surrounded by connective tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following bones do not contribute the nasal septum :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The fleshy external end of the nasal septum is sometimes also called columella. The nasal septum is composed of five structures: • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone • Vomer bone • Cartilage of the septum • Crest of the maxillary bone • Crest of the palatine bone

questions.text: Frontal sinuses appear radiologically at the age of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE OF SINUSES • MAXILLARY---4 MTHS • FRONTAL--- 6 YRS • SPHENOID--- 4 YRS • ETHMOIDAL--- 1 YRS

questions.text: Asymmetrical Congestive Response (The Nasal Cycle) occurs every:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Regulation Response Types 1. Asymmetrical Congestive Response (The Nasal Cycle): Normal physiological congestion/decongestion cycle alternating between nasal sides every 2–7 hours 2. Symmetrical Congestive Response: temporary bilateral congestion induced by exercise, changes in body position, hyperventilation, cold air, sulfur, histamine, and other irritants; lasts 15–30 minutes
